docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurer Anthem Inc, which plans to buy rival Cigna Corp for $47 billion, on Wednesday said medical costs, particularly in its Medicaid and Medicare businesses, were at the low end of expectations and helped boost second-quarter profit.

headline.main: Anthem Profit Beats as Medical Costs Stay at Low End of Estimates
headline.print_headline: Anthem Profit Beats as Medical Costs Stay at Low End of Estimates

docs.snippet: Health insurer Anthem Inc, which plans to buy rival Cigna Corp for $47 billion, on Wednesday said medical costs, particularly in its Medicaid and Medicare businesses, were at the low end of expectations and helped boost second-quarter profit.

docs.lead_paragraph: When President Lyndon B. Johnson signed Medicare and Medicaid into law on July 30, 1965, roughly half of Americans 65 and older had no health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's lasted six years. But now welcome relief from rising U.S. health care costs seems to be winding down.

headline.main: Health Care Spending to Accelerate, US Report Says

docs.lead_paragraph: Opponents of President Barack Obama's soon-to-be-implemented policy to cut carbon emissions from power plants are planning to use an unlikely and potentially potent weapon against him: the recent U.S. Supreme Court decision that saved Obamacare.

headline.main: Obamacare Case to Be Turned Against Government on Emissions Rule
headline.print_headline: Obamacare Case to Be Turned Against Government on Emissions Rule

docs.snippet: Opponents of President Barack Obama's soon-to-be-implemented policy to cut carbon emissions from power plants are planning to use an unlikely and potentially potent weapon against him: the recent U.S. Supreme Court decision that saved Obamacare.

docs.lead_paragraph: The big question is whether health spending will reset to the slow rate of recent years or return to the long-term pattern of high growth.

headline.main: Health Spending Forecast: No Drastic Rise, but Slowdown Seems Over
headline.print_headline: Health Spending Is Expected to Rise as Slowdown Ends

docs.abstract: The Upshot; government actuaries project that national spending on health care will grow at annual rate of 5.8 percent through 2024, significant increase from 4 percent annual growth measured between 2007 and 2013; health spending slowed during Great Recession, and it remains unclear whether it will return to traditional 9 percent annual growth rate once newly-insured are absorbed into system.
docs.snippet: The big question is whether health spending will reset to the slow rate of recent years or return to the long-term pattern of high growth.
